My pet theory is from a little later (and I'm struggling to learn the history of Islam in the Medieval period!) but it's that the Renaissance was sparked by the meeting of East and West facilitated by Islam and some of its more enlightened institutions like the House of Wisdom. When I lecture to high schoolers about Islam, I invite them to consider what factors enabled the Reformation, and have them think about whether Gutenberg's printing press would have been as valuable (when it came to printing the Bible and disseminating it to the non-clerical, non-noble classes) if Islam hadn't united so much of the world and brought to Europe cheap paper and ink from China. When you compare Jesus and Constantine with Muhammad, the situation is a little different. Constantine united Christian clerics and scholars in an attempt to get them to sort out what exactly Christians believe (the first of multiple conclaves, and the unfortunate result of a lot was the excommunication or outright violence against whoever believed something other than these councils decided (like lots of Arians died as a result of Trinitarian theology). Muhammad dictated the Qur'an within his own lifetime and it was collected and organized only a few years later under Umar (2nd Caliph). So Muslims started out knowing universally what they believed and with an excellent pattern for the structure of society. Not a practicing Muslim, although I can make the Shahada without lying. So, philosophically or theologically, maybe it was ordained by God that it was time for that much of the world to be tied together in one culture to push civilization forward one more step?

Something happened to Islam around the  12th-16th centuries when it gradually stopped encouraging scientific knowledge and became increasingly rigid and dogmatic. At some point in its infancy, the Islamic world played an important role in spreading knowledge. Arabic scientists translated the works of ancient Greek and Roman authors and thus saved many of them from oblivion. Today, Islam discourages a scientific view of the world or any kind of creativity, initiative and inquisitiveness. And most of all, Islam discourages progress. I wonder what exactly happened in the 12th-16th centuries and why.

As a very unorthodox Christian (I'm a strict Unitarian as opposed to being Trinitarian), I don't see the creation of any kind of religious "empire," whether it be "Christian," Muslim, or any other religious movement, as being true religion at all. True Christianity was never intended by Jesus or the Apostles to be a state religion or any kind of controlling organization of government. Instead, it was to be a religion of the heart and mind, resulting in the directed effort toward SELF-mastery and virtue, being a "scattered-salt" religion of one here, two or three there, a few over yonder, etc. ANY religion that seeks forced conversion, empire status, control of government, etc. , in any form or fashion whatever; and, whether it be in the name of Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, or any other religion--none of this is from the true God.

96 videos in and Ancient Egypt is still the only civilization in Africa that you have made an episode about. Come on Khan Academy! I thought this was supposed to be "World" History.

Sarcastic tones aside, I think your audience would appreciate several episodes on different African civilizations and how they interact with one another and with the world at large. Speaking for myself, history of Africa before 1800 would be great i.e medieval Mali, Medieval Ethiopia, Great Zimbabwe, the Swahili Coast, Medieval Congo, etc....

On a positive note, it's nice to see that a lot of Asian and Mesoamerican civilizations have been covered on this channel. Keep it up, Khan Academy!
